fine.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: If you want to use cheese instead of chicken, that’s fine.
‘Do you want chili sauce on it?’ ‘No, it’s fine as it is, thanks.’
In theory, the scheme sounds fine.
If Scott wanted to keep his life secret, that was fine by her.
that’s fine by me/that’s fine with me etc
fine.translation[0].definitions[1].examp: ‘How are you?’ ‘Fine, thanks, how are you?’
fine.translation[0].definitions[2].defin: very good or of a very high standard
fine.translation[0].definitions[2].examp: Many people regard Beethoven’s fifth symphony as his finest work.
Hatfield House is a fine example of Jacobean architecture.
The restaurant was chosen for its good food and fine wines.
fine.translation[0].definitions[3].examp: If it’s fine tomorrow we’ll go out.
I hope it stays fine for you.
fine.translation[0].definitions[4].examp: Fine needles are inserted in the arm.
fine.translation[0].definitions[5].examp: Her dark hair accentuates her fine features (=nose, eyes, cheeks etc).
fine.translation[0].definitions[6].defin: fine details, changes, differences etc are very small and therefore difficult to understand or notice
fine.translation[0].definitions[6].examp: We stayed up discussing the finer points of Marxist theory.
fine.translation[0].definitions[7].defin: in small grains, pieces, or drops
fine.translation[0].definitions[7].examp: a mixture of fine and coarse breadcrumbs
fine.translation[0].definitions[8].defin: fine material is made so that the spaces between the threads are very small
fine.translation[0].definitions[8].examp: scarlet cloth with a very fine weave
fine.translation[0].definitions[9].defin: used humorously to say that someone or something is bad in some way
fine.translation[0].definitions[9].examp: That’s another fine mess (=bad situation) he’s got himself into.
You’re a fine one to talk (=you are criticizing someone for something you do yourself).
fine.translation[0].definitions[10].defi: sounding important and impressive, but probably not true or honest
fine.translation[0].definitions[10].exam: Only time will tell whether these fine sentiments will translate into action.
fine.translation[1].definitions[0].defin: in a way that is satisfactory or acceptable
fine.translation[1].definitions[0].examp: If I had a good job and my boyfriend stayed at home, that’d suit me fine (=be very acceptable to me).
fine.translation[1].definitions[1].defin: if you cut something fine, you cut it into very small or very thin pieces
fine.translation[2].definitions[0].defin: to make someone pay money as a punishment
fine.translation[2].definitions[0].examp: The club was fined £50,000 for financial irregularities.
fine.translation[3].definitions[0].defin: money that you have to pay as a punishment
fine.translation[3].definitions[0].examp: Councils will get sweeping powers to impose fines on drivers who park illegally.
She was ordered to pay £150 in parking fines, plus court costs.
pay a fine/pay £100/$50 etc in fines
If convicted, the men face heavy fines.
fine.translation[4].definitions[0].defin: money that someone has to pay as a punishment
fine.translation[4].definitions[0].examp: He served 22 months in jail and paid a $100 million fine to settle insider trading charges.
If convicted, they face heavy fines.
She was ordered to pay £150 in parking fines, plus court costs.
The courts can still impose unlimited fines for water pollution.
fine.translation[5].definitions[0].defin: to make someone pay money as a punishment
fine.translation[5].definitions[0].examp: The company has been fined for illegal nuclear exports to North Korea.
fine.translation[6].definitions[0].defin: of a very high quality or standard
